«Introduction to the Verification»:
Indeed, all praise is due to Allah, we praise Him, seek His help, ask for His forgiveness, and seek His guidance. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our own selves and from our bad deeds. Whomever Allah guides, there is none to mislead him, and whomever He misleads, there is none to guide him. I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, who has no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, may Allah’s peace and blessings be upon him and his family.
As for what follows:
This is a treatise written by the Imam, the Hafiz, the Jurist, Abu al-Faraj Abd al-Rahman bin Rajab al-Hanbali, may Allah have mercy on him, and it relates to an important issue, which is: The disagreement in sighting the crescent moon of Dhu al-Hijjah.

The importance of verifying this treatise is evident in the following points:
1 - The subject for which it was written is an important subject about which people need to know the rulings at all times, due to its connection to a pillar of Islam, which is Hajj, and indeed it relates to its most important pillar, which is standing at Arafat.
2 - The subject of the treatise and other important topics it addresses, such as the disagreement in the crescent moon of Ramadan, and the disagreement in the crescent moon of Shawwal, and others, require knowing the correct opinion regarding them, due to the frequent occurrence of disagreement in each of these issues.
3 - This treatise highlights and addresses a legal ruling that indicates the ease and tolerance of this religion, which is the ruling on the validity of Muslims' acts of worship when they err in the time of the entry of the month of Dhu al-Hijjah, or the time of the entry or exit of the month of Ramadan.
4 - The opinion toward which the author leaned in this important issue brings together the word of Muslims, prevents disagreement, division, and dispersion of the word, and cuts off excessive talk and gossip.

My work on this treatise was limited to the following matters:
1 - Correcting the text, and I have relied on the correct text and indicated others in the footnote.
2 - Studying all the topics addressed by the author by mentioning their evidence briefly, if the author did not address them. If there was a disagreement on the issue that the author did not address, I mentioned it with its evidence somewhat briefly, then mentioned the preponderant opinion and the reason for preponderance.
3 - Documenting (Takhrij) all the Hadiths and Athar cited by the author, mentioning their chains of transmission and supporting evidence, and judging the chain of transmission of each narration in terms of strength and weakness.
The author did not mention a title for this treatise. Ibn Abd al-Hadi mentioned it among the works of Ibn Rajab, and named it: "Rule: Clouding of the Crescent Moon of Dhu al-Hijjah" (1). Perhaps he took this title from the author's saying in the introduction to this treatise: "For an incident occurred in this year, which is the year seven hundred and eighty-four, which is that the crescent moon of Dhu al-Hijjah was clouded over, so people completed the crescent moon of Dhu al-Qa'dah..."

As for what follows:
For an incident occurred in this year, which is the year seven hundred and eighty-four, which is that the crescent moon of Dhu al-Hijjah was clouded over (1), so people completed the crescent moon of Dhu al-Qa'dah. Then people spoke of sighting the crescent moon of Dhu al-Hijjah, and people (2) testified to it whose testimony the judge did not hear. The situation continued on completing the count (3) of the month of Dhu al-Qa'dah. So some people refrained from (4) fasting the ninth (5), which is the Day of Arafah in this year. They said it is the Day of Sacrifice according to what those witnesses whose testimony was not accepted reported. It was said: That some of them sacrificed on that day. And due to that, confusion occurred for the people.
foot_note:
1. (1) Meaning clouds or fog or other things prevented its sighting, from 'Ghamamtu ash-shay'a' if you covered it. See Gharib al-Hadith by Ibn al-Jawzi 2/164, Al-Nihaya fi Gharib al-Hadith 3/388, Al-Misbah al-Munir p. 454.

Do they have the right to fast the day which is apparently the ninth, even if in reality it is the tenth? He answered: Yes, they fast the ninth in the appearance known to the group, even if in reality it is the tenth. Even if that sighting were established, there is in the Sunan from Abu Huraira from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: 'Your fasting is the day you fast, your breaking fast is the day you break fast, and your sacrifice is the day you sacrifice.' Narrated by Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, and Al-Tirmidhi who authenticated it. And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Al-Fitr is the day people break their fast, and Al-Adha is the day people sacrifice.' Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi. And on this is the practice according to all Imams of Muslims. If people stood at Arafah on the tenth day by mistake, their standing suffices them by agreement, and that day was the Day of Arafah in their right. If they stood on the eighth by mistake, there is a dispute regarding sufficiency, and the apparent view is the validity of the standing as well, which is one of the two opinions in the school of Malik and the school of Ahmad and others. Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: 'Arafah is only the day people recognize.' The origin of that is that Allah, Glory be to Him, linked the ruling to the crescent moon and the month. He Almighty said: (They ask you about the new moons. Say, 'They are measurements of time for the people and for Hajj'). Al-Hilal (Crescent Moon): A name for what is announced (yustahallu bihi): i.e., announced and proclaimed. If it rises in the sky and people do not know it and announce it, it is not a crescent moon. Likewise, Al-Shahr (Month) is taken from Al-Shuhrah (Fame/Publicity). If it is not famous among people, the month has not entered. Many people err in this issue, thinking that if it rises in the sky, that night is the first of the month, whether that appeared to people and they announced it or not. It is not so; rather, its appearance to people and their announcement of it is necessary. Therefore, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Your fasting is the day you fast, your breaking fast is the day you break fast, and your sacrifice is the day you sacrifice.' Meaning this day which you know is the time of fasting, breaking fast, and sacrifice. If you do not know it, no ruling is based on it. Fasting the day about which there is doubt: Is it the ninth of Dhu al-Hijjah? Or the tenth of Dhu al-Hijjah? Is permissible without dispute among scholars, because the principle is the non-existence of the tenth, just as if they doubted on the night of the thirtieth of Ramadan whether the crescent moon appeared or did not appear? They fast that doubtful day by the agreement of the Imams. Indeed, the Day of Doubt in which dislike was narrated is the doubt at the beginning of Ramadan, because the principle is the continuation of Sha'ban. End quote.

Al-Walid bin Muslim narrated from Ibn Thawban from his father from Makhul that Umar used to fast if the sun (should be moon) was clouded over on that night, and say: "This is not advancing, but investigation." See Zad al-Ma'ad 2/43. The word "Bin" was dropped from it. Our Sheikh Abd al-Aziz bin Baz said in some of his lessons: "Thawban is not known from his father," and leaned towards the correct reading being: "Ibn Thawban from his father." This is correct, as in the books of narrators. This chain is weak, containing two defects: First: Ibn Thawban - who is Abd al-Rahman bin Thabit bin Thawban - there is disagreement regarding his reliability. Imam Ahmad said: "His hadiths are Munkar (rejected)." Salih bin Muhammad said: "Truthful, they rejected hadiths he narrates from his father from Makhul." Abu Hatim said: "Trustworthy, his mind changed at the end of his life but he is upright in hadith." See Tahdhib al-Tahdhib 6/150, 151. Second: Makhul did not meet Umar, so it is interrupted (Munqati'). Al-Iraqi declared it defective in Tarh al-Tathrib 4/110. Al-Shafi'i narrated in Al-Umm 2/94, and from his path Al-Daraqutni 2/170, and Al-Bayhaqi 4/212 from Al-Darawardi from Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Uthman from Fatima bint Husayn that a man testified before Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding his sighting of the crescent moon, so he fasted, and I think he ordered people to fast, and said: "That I fast a day of Sha'ban is more beloved to me than that I break fast a day of Ramadan." Its chain is weak. Al-Darawardi has weakness in his narration, and Fatima bint Husayn did not meet her grandfather Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, for she is among the junior Tabi'in. See Al-Thiqat 5/300, 301, Tahdhib al-Kamal plate 1692. It is said in Al-Majmu' 6/403: "Al-Abdari said: It is not authentic from him." In Al-Talkhis 2/211: "It contains interruption." Al-Iraqi said in Tarh al-Tathrib 4/110: "It is interrupted, then he only said it upon the testimony of one regarding the sighting of the crescent moon, not in cloudiness." See Nayl al-Awtar 4/266, 267. Abu Dawood narrated 2/298, number (1329), and from his path Al-Bayhaqi in Al-Kubra 4/210, 211 from Al-Mughira bin Farwah from Muawiyah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We saw the crescent moon on such and such day, and I am advancing the fast, so whoever likes to do so let him do so. Its chain is weak. "Al-Mughira bin Farwah" was not authenticated by anyone except Ibn Hibban. See Al-Thiqat 5/410, and Tahdhib al-Tahdhib 10/268. The hadith is in Da'if Sunan Abi Dawood. Imam Ahmad narrated - as in Zad al-Ma'ad 2/44 - from Al-Mughira, Sa'id bin Abd al-Aziz told us, he said: Makhul and Yunus bin Maysarah bin Halbas told me that Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan used to say: "That I fast a day of Sha'ban is more beloved to me than that I break fast a day of Ramadan." Its chain is weak. Sa'id bin Abd al-Aziz - who is Al-Tanukhi - became confused at the end. See Al-Kawakib al-Nayyirat p. 213-220. Al-Mughira, I did not determine who he is. Makhul did not meet Muawiyah. As for Yunus bin Maysarah, his hearing from him is disputed, but it is more likely he heard from him, for he was killed in 132 AH at the age of 120, so his age at Muawiyah's death would be 58, and he is Damascene. Yahya bin Ma'in affirmed his hearing from him. See Tahdhib al-Kamal plate 1571. Ibn al-Jawzi narrated it in Al-Ilal al-Mutanahiyah 2/38 via Makhul similarly to the first narration. It is interrupted, Makhul did not meet Muawiyah. Imam Ahmad also narrated - as in Zad al-Ma'ad 2/44 - from Zaid bin al-Hubbab, Ibn Lahi'ah informed us from Abdullah bin Hubayrah from Amr bin al-Aas that he used to fast the day doubted to be of Ramadan. Ibn Lahi'ah is disputed, and Abdullah bin Hubayrah is not mentioned to have heard from Amr, and his age at his death was close to ten years or slightly more, and he is Egyptian. See Tahdhib al-Tahdhib 6/61, 62. Imam Ahmad narrated - as in Zad al-Ma'ad 2/44 - from Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi, Muawiyah bin Salih told us from Abu Maryam, the freed slave of Abu Huraira, who said: I heard Abu Huraira saying: That I hasten in fasting Ramadan by a day is more beloved to me than that I delay, because if I hasten I do not miss it, and if I delay I miss it. Its chain is Hasan, its men are trustworthy, except Muawiyah bin Salih - who is Al-Hadrami - for he is truthful (Saduq) having delusions, as in Al-Taqrib p. 538. Al-Khatib said - as in Al-Majmu' 6/632: "As for what we narrated from Muawiyah bin Salih from Abu Maryam - he mentioned it - then said: A weak narration not preserved except from this aspect, and Abu Maryam is unknown, so it does not contradict what the Hafiz narrated from the companions of Abu Huraira from him." End quote. What he mentioned of Abu Maryam's obscurity is not accepted, for Al-Ijli authenticated him, and Imam Ahmad reported from the people of Homs that he is known among them and they praised him well. See Tarikh al-Thiqat p. 510, and Tahdhib al-Tahdhib 12/231, 232. Al-Bayhaqi narrated this Athar in his Sunan al-Kubra 4/211 via Zaid bin Habban from Muawiyah bin Salih similarly. Imam Ahmad narrated as in Zad al-Ma'ad 2/43, 44 from Isma'il bin Ibrahim, Yahya bin Abi Ishaq told us, he said: I saw the crescent moon either at noon or close to it, so some people broke fast. We came to Anas bin Malik and informed him of seeing the crescent moon and the breaking of fast by those who broke fast. He said: I am fasting tomorrow, so I disliked differing from him, so I fasted, and I am completing this day of mine until night. Its chain is Hasan, its men are trustworthy, except Yahya bin Abi Ishaq - who is Al-Hadrami - for he is truthful (Saduq) perhaps erring as in Al-Taqrib p. 587. Al-Khatib said after mentioning this Athar: "The opponent said: Anas does not advance the fast of the group except by fasting the Day of Doubt. It is said: Anas said he did not fast it believing it obligatory, but he followed Al-Hakam bin Ayyub - who was the Emir - in abstaining during it, and perhaps the Emir resolved upon him in that so he disliked opposing him. What is preserved from Anas is that he broke fast on the Day of Doubt, as Muhammad bin Sirin narrated from him, and suffice with him in understanding, intellect, truthfulness, and virtue." See Al-Majmu' 6/432, 433. Abd al-Razzaq narrated in his Musannaf 4/159, number (7317), and Ibn Abi Shaybah 3/71 via Muhammad bin Sirin from Anas a narration indicating he broke fast on the Day of Doubt. Its chain is authentic, its men are men of the Two Sheikhs. Al-Tabarani narrated similarly via Muhammad bin Ka'b al-Qurazi. Al-Haythami authenticated its chain in Majma' al-Bahrain 3/103. Al-Bayhaqi narrated in his Sunan 4/209 similarly via Hammam from Qatada. Imam Ahmad narrated from Ruh bin Ubadah from Hammad bin Salamah from Hisham bin Urwa from Fatima from Asma' that she used to fast the day doubted to be of Ramadan. See Zad al-Ma'ad 2/45. "Ruh bin Ubadah" was misspelled as "Ruh bin Abbad" and our Sheikh Abd al-Aziz bin Baz corrected it in some of his lessons. The chain of this narration is connected, and its men are trustworthy, except that Hammad bin Salamah's memory changed at the end. Yahya bin Durais followed Hammad in Al-Bayhaqi's Al-Kubra 4/211 so Hammad's narration is strengthened by this follow-up. Sa'id bin Mansur narrated as in Zad al-Ma'ad 2/45 from Ya'qub bin Abd al-Rahman from Hisham bin Urwa from Fatima bint al-Mundhir who said: The crescent moon of Ramadan was never clouded over except that Asma' was advancing by a day, and ordering advancing it. Its chain is authentic, its men are men of the Two Sahihs. Fasting the Day of Doubt or the opinion of fasting it has been narrated from Salim bin Abdullah, Umar bin Abd al-Aziz, Mujahid, Tawus, Abu Uthman al-Nahdi, Mutarrif bin al-Shikhkhir, Maymun bin Mahran, Bakr bin Abdullah al-Muzani, and Ibn Abi Maryam. text: And it was narrated from Abu Huraira as his own statement (Mawquf) (1). And Al-Saffah bin Matar narrated from Abdul Aziz bin Abdullah bin Khalid bin Asid: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The Day of Arafah is the day the people know/gather" - a Hasan Mursal (2), which Imam Ahmad used as proof.
foot_note:
1. (1) Al-Bayhaqi said after narrating the previous Hadith: 'Ibn Ulayyah and Abdul Wahhab al-Thaqafi narrated it from Ayyub from Muhammad bin al-Munkadir from Abu Huraira as Mawquf.'
2. Al-Daraqutni narrated it in Hajj 2/223, 224, and from his path Al-Bayhaqi in Al-Sunan Al-Kubra in Hajj, Chapter: The People's Mistake regarding the Day of Arafah 5/174 via the path of Hushaym from Al-Awwam bin Hawshab from Al-Saffah bin Matar with it. Its chain is weak. It has three defects: First: It is Mursal - as the author mentioned - for Abdul Aziz bin Abdullah bin Khalid is a Tabi'i who did not meet the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. See Al-Marasil by Abu Dawood p. 139, and Al-Taqrib p. 357. Second: Al-Saffah bin Matar was not documented as trustworthy by anyone except Ibn Hibban in Kitab al-Thiqat 6/435, and in Al-Taqrib p. 243 he is said to be: 'Maqbul' (Acceptable). Third: Hushaym - who is Ibn Bashir - is a Mudallis (one who conceals defects in the chain), and he used 'an' (from). See Ta'rif Ahl al-Taqdis by Ibn Hajar p. 115. Al-Bayhaqi said: 'This is a good (Jayyid) Mursal.' It has a supporting narration (Shahid) which is not to be rejoiced at; Al-Daraqutni narrated it in the previous location via Al-Waqidi from Ibn Abi Sabrah from Ya'qub bin Zaid bin Talha al-Taymi from his father from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: 'Arafah is the day the people know/stand.' Al-Waqidi is abandoned as in Al-Taqrib p. 498, and Zaid bin Talha is a Tabi'i, see Al-Tarikh al-Kabir 3/398 and Al-Thiqat 4/249, so it is Mursal. In general, this Hadith is Sahih from the Hadith of Abu Huraira with the wording: 'Fasting is the day the people fast, and Fitr is the day they break fast, and Adha is the day they sacrifice.' A group of scholars authenticated or declared it Hasan, including Al-Nawawi in Al-Majmu' 5/27, Al-Subki in the treatise Al-Ilm al-Manshur fi Ithbat al-Shuhur p. 18, Al-Suyuti in Al-Jami' al-Saghir (Fayd al-Qadir 4/441), Al-Azim Abadi in Al-Ta'liq al-Mughni 2/224, Ahmad Shakir in his treatise: 'The Beginnings of Arabic Months...' p. 24, Muhammad Nasir al-Din in Al-Irwa 4/11, Shu'aib al-Arna'ut in his commentary on Sharh al-Sunnah 6/248, and Abdul Qadir al-Arna'ut in his commentary on Jami' al-Usul 6/278. Interpretation of this Hadith differed: 'Some scholars interpreted this Hadith saying: The meaning of this is: That Fasting and Fitr are with the community and the majority of people.' Imam Al-Khattabi said in Ma'alim al-Sunan 3/213: 'The meaning of the Hadith is that error is lifted from the people in matters subject to Ijtihad. If a people strove (did Ijtihad) and did not see the crescent until after the thirtieth, so they did not break fast until they completed the number, then it was established among them that the month was twenty-nine, their fasting and breaking fast is valid, and there is no sin or hardship upon them. Likewise in Hajj, if they mistook the day of Arafah, there is no repetition upon them, and their Adha suffices them as well. This is only a lightening from Allah Almighty and kindness to His servants. If they were tasked to repeat if they mistook the number, they would not be safe from mistaking a second time, nor safe from error a third and fourth time, for whatever is subject to Ijtihad, error is not secure in it.' The majority of scholars agreed with Imam Al-Khattabi on this interpretation. See Nayl al-Awtar 3/383. Qadi Al-Subki opposed them in interpreting this Hadith in Kitab al-Ilm al-Manshur p. 18, saying after mentioning this Hadith: 'And its meaning, and Allah knows best, is if the people gather on that, they are not tasked with what might be in the reality of the matter which they did not know.' And he said on p. 51 of this book after mentioning the Hanafi view: That if they counted Sha'ban as thirty based on a sighting, then fasted twenty-eight and saw the crescent, they make up a day, because they erred. He said: 'So that from the Hanafis indicates that Fasting is not the day you fast by mistake, and Fitr is not the day you break fast by mistake. Rather, the meaning of the Hadith is: The day you fast the correct Fast and break the correct Fitr.' The closest interpretation of this Hadith is what Imam At-Tirmidhi quoted from some scholars, for it aligns with the statement of Mother of the Believers Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, and no opponent from the Prophet's companions is known for her. They argued with what is in the two Sahihs from Al-Bara' raised: 'Whoever sacrifices before the prayer, he has only slaughtered for himself, and whoever sacrifices after the prayer, his rite is complete and he has hit the Sunnah of the Muslims.' They said these Hadiths indicate that what counts is the finishing of the prayer, not the slaughter of the Imam. The Hadith of Ibn Jurayj from Abu al-Zubayr from Jabir was answered by saying Hammad bin Salamah contradicted him and narrated it from Abu al-Zubayr from Jabir with the wording: 'He forbade that they slaughter before he prays,' narrated by Al-Tahawi and Ibn Hibban. In the chain of this narration is the 'an'ana of Abu al-Zubayr, who is a Mudallis. They said: This narration agrees with the Hadiths indicating that slaughter begins after the prayer, not after the Imam's slaughter. The preponderant view in this issue is the opinion of the Majority, due to the strength of their evidences. The Hadith of Jabir is interpreted as deterrence from haste which might lead to doing it before the time. See Sharh Muslim by Al-Nawawi 13/118.

So his error and negligence are upon him, not upon the Muslims who were not negligent or mistaken. There is no doubt that it is proven by the authentic Sunnah and consensus of the Companions that it is not permissible to rely on the calculation of stars, as proven from him, peace and blessings be upon him, in the two Sahihs that he said: "We are an unlettered nation, we do not write or calculate. The one relying on calculation regarding the crescent, just as he is astray in Sharia and an innovator in religion, he is mistaken in reason and the science of calculation, for scholars of astronomy know that sighting is not regulated by a calculable matter.' The correct view in the issue is what the author leaned towards and mentioned as the analogy of the Madhhab: that whoever saw the crescent of Dhu al-Hijjah and his word was not accepted, and whoever was informed of its sighting by someone he trusts, if he wants Hajj, he must stand on the Day of Arafah with the group of Muslims. Likewise, it is recommended for him to fast it if he is not a pilgrim, even if according to what is established with him it is the tenth day. Because the Hadith 'Your fasting is the day you fast, your breaking fast is the day you break fast, and your sacrifice is the day you sacrifice' - which is a Sahih Hadith as preceded p. (24) - is explicit that the Day of Sacrifice for the entire Ummah is the day the Imam and the community of Muslims sacrifice and pray the Eid prayer in, even if it is the eleventh day according to what was established with some Muslims from sighting. Based on this, the Day of Arafah is the day the Imam and the community of Muslims stand at Arafat. This is what is established from Mother of the Believers Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, as preceded completely (19-21) - and no opponent from the Companions is known for her. But if a person wants to be cautious for himself and stand on the eighth day at Arafah which is, according to what is established with him, the Day of Arafah, then stand with the people the next day as Salim bin Abdullah, may Allah have mercy on him, did - and his action was previously mentioned p. (31, 32) - or leave fasting the Day of Arafah which is, according to what is established with him, the Day of Eid if he is not a pilgrim, as Masruq and others did - and their action was previously mentioned p. (19-21) - there is no harm in that, escaping from the disagreement of those who obligated him to act upon what is established with him like Al-Subki in the book Al-Ilm al-Manshur fi Ithbat al-Shuhur p. 45, 46. This is the analogy of the saying of one who said the one who sees the crescent of Ramadan alone fasts, as mention of who said that preceded p. (). It is also the analogy of the saying of one who said: He breaks fast if he sees the crescent of Shawwal alone, as mention of who said that preceded p. (29, 30). But whoever does that should hide his action to prevent division and scattering the word, and lest the common people doubt the validity of their action. All this applies if the one establishing the entry of the month relies on sighting, as is the case in this country, praise be to Allah. But if he relies on calculation, or does not accept the testimony of witnesses if it contradicts calculation, then he who saw it or was informed of its sighting by someone he trusts must act upon what is established with him from sighting, and leave what is other than it - this is also what the author leaned towards, as preceded p. (). In this case, he should show his action to the people and teach others what is established with him, unless he fears that calling to act by this legal ruling will result in a greater evil, then he should leave calling to it at that time. And Allah knows best.
